stream_context.summary: Kaze battles a sudden Blender/Fast64 toolchain crash that blocks access to the overworld scene, troubleshoots versions/PR fixes to recover the file, then continues overworld iteration: closes an unintended long-jump skip, tests updated Project64 and F3DEX3 compatibility, verifies the game running on real N64 hardware via SC64 deployment, and implements new overworld NPC/state logic (Boatrice) plus plans for Dory/Plessie as the unlock for the second overworld.
stream_context.significance_reason: A workflow-threatening Fast64/Blender crash is diagnosed as Fast64-related and worked around; Kaze also demonstrates a practical real-hardware deployment pipeline (SC64 + HDMI-modded N64) and locks in key overworld progression beats (skip fix, Boatrice state machine, Dory unlocking overworld 2).

findings.summary: The level-editing workflow was blocked for ~30 minutes because Blender would crash when opening the overworld .blend; disabling Fast64 didn’t immediately resolve it, and appending the scene failed. Kaze concludes it’s a Fast64/Blender-version interaction affecting multiple levels, not an isolated file.

A community PR/fix (from Lilaa, referred to once as “Lina”) allowed the file to open under a newer Blender/Fast64 combination, but Kaze identifies constraints: newer Blender/Fast64 (4.5.x) can’t upgrade or work cleanly with older material setups, forcing careful version/tool selection.
findings.quote: So it is a Fast64 thing. So it is a Fast64 thing. So it is a Fast64 thing.

findings.summary: Kaze notes he keeps many Fast64 versions locally (“30 different versions”), implying the pipeline is brittle enough that rollback/side-by-side installs are necessary to keep production moving.
Kaze shows an updated emulator build (“Luna’s Project64,” updated for him by Eclab) because a newer F3DEX3 update introduced features the project wants, and older emulators were incompatible.

Kaze verifies RTYI running on original N64 hardware (what he calls “Unreal Hardware”), using a Summercats HDMI mod and an SC64 deployer workflow that can upload ROMs (and even saves) directly via a script.
findings.quote: Playing this on Unreal Hardware is like half the point.

findings.summary: He fixes a major overworld exploit: Mario could long-jump to skip the entire “second Bowser area.” Kaze redesigns the rock/geometry (“form follows function”) to block the shortcut and then tests the skip to confirm it’s patched.
Kaze adds/places a save block in the area and later decides a ground-poundable object interaction should also trigger a save because it feels satisfying and marks progress.
Kaze rethinks an optional blue-coin switch because it detracts from the main beat (Boatrice). He replaces it with a single blue coin to keep the space active without stealing focus.

He implements Boatrice as an overworld NPC with story-gated state: she’s initially hidden/transparent, fades in when approached/talked to, then disappears permanently and reappears later in “Rainbow Grotto” near her husband. Kaze begins drafting old-fashioned dialogue, acknowledging Biobak is stronger at writing text.

Boatrice’s transparency introduces render-order artifacts (limbs/face draw order). Kaze accepts this as mostly visible only during opacity transitions and tweaks opacity behavior (e.g., 1–10% before story completion) to minimize the noticeable glitch.

Kaze states a content rule: RTYI avoids referencing Mario games beyond the N64 era (no later-era callbacks/power moons), positioning RTYI as a more direct N64-feeling sequel rather than a reference-heavy remix.
findings.quote: We’re not referencing Mario games after Mario 64, or after the N64.

findings.summary: Performance/asset constraints come up during model review: Kaze reacts to a stylized Shy Guy model (~328 triangles) as high compared to typical SM64 enemy budgets (~140 triangles), reinforcing a recurring optimization target mindset.

Kaze outlines a core progression plan: Dory/Plessie will be chained/anchored until the first Bowser star; after that she’s freed and becomes the traversal vehicle to reach and unlock the second overworld, with Yoshi riding on her back.
Kaze mentions Biobak is doing a broad rework pass across the game’s levels (at the moment focusing on “Ice Cap”), affecting what Kaze chooses to fix now versus waiting for incoming updates.

biobak.summary: Biobak is reportedly “doing a rework of every level,” and at this moment is working on the Ice Cap level, which changes Kaze’s priorities (he avoids fixing certain issues until Biobak’s update lands).

findings.summary: Provided or linked a PR/fix to address the Blender/Fast64 crash that prevented opening the overworld .blend, and advised on version/PR selection (e.g., “4.5 fixed PR”).
Kaze asks Lilaa for Fast64 usability improvements (e.g., adding a GeoASM hook before the first armature spawn) and for Blender UX help after cursor behavior changes in newer Blender versions.
findings.quote: That’s actually a huge usability issue if you can’t write a define in here.

findings.summary: Updated Kaze’s emulator build (“Luna’s Project64”) to support recent F3DEX3 changes and features that RTYI wants to use, because previous emulators weren’t compatible.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Man, having the overworld mostly in the game feels good. It’s like now I’m playing an actual game.
memorable_quotes.context: Said early while traversing the overworld, capturing a shift from “dev project” to “playable world,” which is a strong documentary beat about morale and momentum.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Playing this on Unreal Hardware is like half the point.
memorable_quotes.context: During the real-N64 demonstration, framing hardware authenticity as a core motivation—not a bonus feature.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Don’t put real in quotation marks, this is literally just an N64.
memorable_quotes.context: He pushes back on chat skepticism while showing HDMI-modded hardware footage, reinforcing the project’s “no tricks” ethos.

key_stories.title: Fast64/Blender crash blocks the overworld workflow
key_stories.summary: The stream opens with a sudden production-stopping tool failure: Kaze can’t open the overworld Blender file, and even appending scenes doesn’t work. The recovery becomes a real-time example of how fragile ROM-hack tooling can be—and how the team relies on community fixes to keep moving.
key_stories.challenge: Blender crashes when opening the overworld .blend (and at least one other level), preventing any level editing and threatening overworld progress.
key_stories.process: Kaze tests disabling Fast64/Fast64 Render, tries appending into a new file, experiments with multiple Blender/Fast64 versions (4.2.x vs 4.5.x), and applies a community PR/fix. He diagnoses it as a Fast64-related issue with version-specific limitations around older materials.
key_stories.outcome: He regains access to the level and continues development, but leaves the stream with evidence the pipeline is brittle and may recur across levels/tool versions.
key_stories.key_quote: If I can’t open my level, how the fuck are we supposed to work?

key_stories.title: Real N64 deployment becomes part of the dev loop
key_stories.summary: Mid-stream, Kaze demonstrates RTYI running on original N64 hardware and explains a fast deploy workflow. This is a “proof of reality” moment: performance, visuals, and even upload tooling are validated outside emulation, strengthening the project’s authenticity theme.
key_stories.challenge: New F3DEX3 updates require emulator compatibility changes, and the project’s goal includes running on original hardware reliably.
key_stories.process: Kaze switches to “Luna’s Project64” (updated by Eclab for F3DEX3 compatibility), then shows a Summercats HDMI-modded N64 setup and an SC64 deployer script that uploads ROMs (and saves) to the console.
key_stories.outcome: RTYI is shown running on an actual N64 with a repeatable upload pipeline, reinforcing hardware-first validation as a development pillar.
key_stories.key_quote: Don’t put real in quotation marks, this is literally just an N64.

key_stories.title: Blocking an unintended overworld skip (form follows function)
key_stories.summary: Kaze finds a traversal exploit that lets players long-jump over geometry to skip a major overworld section (“second Bowser area”). He treats it as a design/structure problem and reshapes the environment to enforce intended progression.
key_stories.challenge: Players can long-jump past the second Bowser area, bypassing content and potentially breaking progression.
key_stories.process: Kaze remodels/adjusts the rock and collision so the jump line no longer works, then repeatedly tests the long-jump route to verify the fix.
key_stories.outcome: The skip is no longer achievable in testing, restoring intended pacing and gating.

key_stories.title: Boatrice: a story-gated NPC with fade-in visibility and relocation
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements a new overworld character (Boatrice) with state-driven appearance rules, including transparency and relocation after conversation. The segment shows how story beats get translated into N64-era engine constraints (opacity, draw order, text IDs).
key_stories.challenge: Make an NPC that feels mysterious (initially hidden/transparent), becomes interactable, then disappears and later reappears elsewhere—without modern engine conveniences.
key_stories.process: Kaze adds fade-in behavior tied to proximity/dialogue, handles render-order artifacts during transparency transitions, assigns text box IDs (working around parameter mistakes), and drafts placeholder “old-timey” dialogue. He removes/adjusts shadow and hover speed to fit the character.
key_stories.outcome: Boatrice can be talked to; she fades in during dialogue, then disappears and is set to appear later in Rainbow Grotto near her husband. Text is functional but explicitly not final.

open_questions.context: Kaze experiences repeat crashes opening certain .blend level files, believes it’s Fast64-related, and notes it’s the second level affected. He works around it via version/PR juggling, but doesn’t identify a root cause.
questions: What specifically corrupted or destabilized the Blender scene—materials, armatures, plugin state, or a Blender API change?
How often has this happened across RTYI, and did it ever permanently cost work?
Do you now have a standard “safe workflow” (versions pinned, export steps, CI checks) to prevent this from happening again?

open_questions.topic: F3DEX3 update: which features RTYI is betting on
open_questions.context: Kaze says F3DEX3 was updated with “cool new features” the team wants, and he needed a new emulator to be compatible.
questions: Which specific F3DEX3 features are you using (or planning to use), and what do they enable visually or performance-wise?
Did adding F3DEX3 features force any tradeoffs (compatibility, debugging difficulty, stricter budgets)?
How do you decide when a renderer/toolchain upgrade is worth the risk during production?

open_questions.topic: Hardware-first development: how it changes decisions
open_questions.context: Kaze demonstrates SC64-based deployment and insists real N64 playability is central to the project’s purpose.
questions: At what milestones do you require real-hardware verification (per level, per feature, per release candidate)?
What problems only show up on-console (timing, RSP/RDP bottlenecks, depth issues, artifacts) that emulation misses?
How did the SC64 workflow change your productivity compared to older flashcart/testing methods?

open_questions.topic: Overworld 2 unlock design (Dory/Plessie + Yoshi) and anti-skip constraints
open_questions.context: Kaze describes Dory being chained/anchored until the first Bowser star, then freed to carry Yoshi and serve as the vehicle to reach the second overworld. He’s concerned about placement enabling warps/skips.
questions: Why make Dory the unlock for overworld 2—what feeling or story beat are you aiming for compared to a door/key/portal?
How will you prevent sequence breaks once players can interact with Dory (warps, unintended ledges, speedrun movement)?
What will the ‘freeing’ moment look like mechanically and cinematically on N64 constraints?
